fullText:
Super Bowl LX 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
 All the ads and trailers from the big game

Winners, snubs and surprises from music's major night

Netflix, Paramount Skydance face off

The former co-anchor came on the show in support of Savannah Guthrie and her missing mother, saying: "This whole thing is breaking my heart."

Busfield is accused of groping a 7-year-old boy on the set of "The Cleaning Lady." He has adamantly denied the charges.

Neon has acquired worldwide rights to twin filmmakers’ Arie and Chuko Esiri’s “Clarissa.”

 Shot on 35mm film in Lagos and Delta State, Nigeria, the film stars Sophie…

After a strong backlash over a racist video of the Obamas that was posted to President Donald Trump’s account on Truth Social, the video has been deleted.

 A White…

M. Night Shyamalan’s “Remain,” a romantic drama that also inspired Nicholas Sparks’ best-selling novel of the same name, will hit theaters on February 5, 2027.

 The…

Domhnall Gleeson, Greta Lee, Jodie Turner-Smith and a pet rock star alongside Swift.

The two discuss 'Wicked: For Good,' what makes them cry and loving 'The Waterboy.'

The two on their life-changing 'Mummy' friendship, loneliness and learning to stop trying so hard.

A Variety and iHeartRadio Podcast

Rachel McAdams thrives on a desert island in Sam Raimi's twisted survival thriller. Going back to his roots, Raimi wickedly flips the dynamic between a number cruncher and her nightmare boss.

In a mockumentary that plays it straight, Charli xcx is teamed with a doofus director (Alexander Skarsgård) who wants to clean up her image. But why would any version of Charli xcx say yes?

Brett Ratner's First Lady documentary is a cheeseball infomercial of staggering inertia. There's no drama to a film that should have been called "Day of the Living Tradwife."

The first feature by the YouTube gamer personality Markiplier is a murky sci-fi horror tale that confines us to a midget submarine. The claustrophobic perils are plentiful but wear thin.

'Interior Chinatown' Struggles to Turn an Allegorical Novel Into a Show

HBO Prequel Series 'Dune: Prophecy' Capably Tailors the Epic Franchise to Television

Taylor Sheridan's 'Landman' Gives the West Texas Oil Fields the 'Yellowstone' Treatment

Eddie Redmayne and Lashana Lynch's 'The Day of the Jackal' Is an Exhilarating Assassin Thriller

Billie Eilish and producer Finneas keep up their winning streak with a surprising and intimate third album.

Childish Gambino's latest is a masterpiece, and a kaleidoscopic showcase for his seemingly endless talents.

Vince Staples searches for light on his new album, his most vulnerable project to date.

Dua Lipa's new album is a joyous blast of pop savvy.

Sam Gold's production is an actorly face-off between Jeremy Strong and Michael Imperioli, but the script ultimately let's the audience off the hook.

Patricia Clarkson gives a luminous performance in an otherwise uneven revival of Eugene O'Neill's family drama.

The stage adaptation has escapism, enchantment and heart, all elevated to new, literal heights that blend theater and cirque.

Popular on Variety

 
 
 

 

 
 
 ‘Joybubbles’ Director Rachael Morrison and Editors Bradford Thomason and Patrick Lawrence on Their Retro Phone Hacker Doc
 
 
 

 
 
 Perfection is rarely achieved in movies, but this heaven-sent concert doc hits the sweet spot. Over two days in January 1972, the Queen of Soul, Aretha Franklin — she was 29 at the time — sweeps into the New Temple Missionary Baptist Church in Watts in front of a congregation and testifies to God in song. The blessed thing took nearly half a century to come out because director Sydney Pollack failed to sync the image with the sound. Then digital angels stepped in, and glory, glory, hallelujah!

dtliExcerpt: This jukebox musical built around the songs of Johnny Cash feels more like a reverent tribute concert than a fully realized theatrical experience.
showScoreExcerpt: This jukebox musical built around the songs of Johnny Cash feels more like a reverent tribute concert than a fully realized theatrical experience.

keyPhrases.quote: This jukebox musical built around the songs of Johnny Cash feels more like a reverent tribute concert than a fully realized theatrical experience.

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-unanimous] | All 4 models agree: Mixed | Claude: Single excerpt warning applies - this critique suggests the show lacks theatrical depth despite being 'reverent,' indicating mixed feelings rather than clear recommendation or dismissal. | GPT-4o: The excerpt suggests the show lacks theatrical depth, resembling a tribute concert rather than a complete theatrical work. Without more context, it's unclear if this is a positive or negative sentiment, leading to a mixed classification. | Gemini: The review excerpt suggests a lack of theatrical depth, leaning more towards a concert experience. This indicates a mixed assessment, not fully negative but not entirely positive either. | Kimi: The critic acknowledges the show's respectful treatment of the music but criticizes its failure to transcend concert format and achieve full theatrical realization, indicating a mixed reception with notable reservations about the production's artistic ambitions.

rejectionReasoning: claude: This text is a garbled mix of website navigation, unrelated articles about Disney, SNL, and various other topics, with repeated paragraphs about an Aretha Franklin documentary. No coherent Broadway review is present.; openai: The text provided is a collection of unrelated headlines and snippets, not a coherent review of the target show.; gemini: This is a list of headlines and short descriptions of various articles, not a review of a specific show.; kimi: The provided text is a collection of unrelated entertainment news snippets, headlines, and partial reviews from Variety's website (including TV news, movie reviews, and music coverage), not a coherent Broadway review article. It contains repeated paragraphs and appears to be navigation content or a sidebar aggregation rather than a focused critique of a single show.
